notes: Type 30 brass-era model (1909-1911). Inline-4 engine with innovation in interchangeable parts (won Dewar Trophy 1908). Multiple body styles available. Brass radiator, acetylene/oil lamps, hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes rear only. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects brass-era construction, hand-fitted components, pioneering interchangeable parts (but still vintage), and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type 30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 51 with first production V8 engine (1914-1916). Industry-first mass-produced V8. Electric starter and lights standard (major innovation). Multiple luxury body styles. Brass-era construction with modern features. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects WWI-era brass construction, pioneering V8 technology, hand-assembled components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type 51 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 53/55/57/59/61 series evolution (1916-1923). Continued V8 engine development through WWI and early 1920s. Multiple body styles with coachwork. Transitioned from brass-era to modern construction. Type numbers changed yearly. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects WWI/early-1920s vintage, brass-era proximity, transition technologies, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 61 V8-powered luxury sedan (1916-1917). Established Cadillac's V8 reputation. Electric starter and lights standard. Multiple body styles available. WWI-era production. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects WWI brass-era construction, early V8 technology, hand-fitted components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type 61 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
